column4: hello. when i want to mount a external HD. How do i know which /dev/sda to mount?
it should show up automatically in places, but you can use dmesg to find the drive after you plug it in
ah ok...it shows /dev/sdb1 how do i then mount this?
mount -t <filesystem> <mountpoint>
how do i know the filesystem?
mount -t <filesystem> /dev/sdb1 <mountpoint>
i missed the device part; to know the filesystem you can use parted, or if you formatted it, you should remember :)
parted? will it do anything to the disk or will it just inspect it?
parted _can_ do things to it, you have to be careful
do "sudo parted /dev/sdb" then in parted hit "p" for print, and it will tell you the filesystem
then hit "q" to exit parted
usually it works like that
you're trying to add a ppa to update the kernel? why?
no im trying to update php to 5.4
then why is the kernel in there
no idea
it was already there i think
which ppa are you using
im using this: https://launchpad.net/~ondrej/+archive/php5
open up synaptic and mark all the upgrades
cant i just upgrade everything with a command?
you'd probably have to specify what to upgrade, because something in those upgrades requires the removal of something else most likely
ok...now i opened the update manager. I think it will work fine
